articles.title: Six-yearly count to track diverging fortunes of UK and Ireland’s wintering swans
articles.trailText: The international swan census takes place this weekend, with volunteers helping count whooper and Bewick’s swans
articles.summary: Volunteer birders across the UK and Ireland will join the six-yearly international swan census this weekend to count wintering whooper and Bewick’s swans. Conducted last in January 2020, the survey spans Iceland, continental Europe, central Asia and the Black Sea. Data reveal diverging trends: UK whooper numbers have nearly doubled over 25 years to around 20,000, while Bewick’s have crashed to roughly 700, concentrated in southern England. Researchers attribute these shifts to climate-driven milder winters altering migration and survival patterns.

Other amended items include an MP’s school visit blocked by pro-Palestine protesters, Greenland’s PM endorsing Denmark over the US, New Zealand’s kākāpō breeding boom and Netflix’s Stranger Things Conformity Gate glitch. articles.title: Trump’s imperial measures: inside the 16 January edition of Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: The new age of empire. Plus: Interview with film director Park Chan-wook
articles.summary: Guardian Weekly’s 16 January edition probes Trump’s new ‘age of empire’: revanchist US foreign-policy thrusts from Venezuela to Greenland and domestic unrest after ICE agent killing Renee Nicole Good, defended by the president. Julian Borger warns these moves mark a break from the postwar rules-based order toward overt imperialism alongside Putin and Xi. The issue also examines Iran’s brutal protest crackdown and includes five essential reads on Iran demonstrations, Elon Musk’s Grok AI scandal, Trump’s attack on the Smithsonian, Gaza garden resistance and a Park Chan-wook interview.

articles.title: ‘The locals don’t really benefit’: the dark side of Detty December party season
articles.trailText: What began as a welcoming home for many in the global Black diaspora is threatening to cause frictions that no amount of fun can resolve
articles.summary: The article critiques the rapid growth of the Detty December festivities—once an organic homecoming for the Black diaspora in cities like Lagos, Accra, and coastal Kenyan towns—now fueled by Afrobeats hype and Ghana’s Year of Return. Recent years saw mass tourism inflate prices, squeeze local families, and erode genuine ties, as chargebacks and entitled visitor behavior strain small businesses. Infrastructure gridlock and transactional relationships highlight that, despite the glamour, the seasonal influx yields few lasting benefits for local communities.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

articles.title: Israelis demonised as a ‘vehicle for hatred of Jews’, says UK terror laws watchdog
articles.trailText: Jonathan Hall calls for police forces to clamp down on racial hatred based on nationality
articles.summary: Jonathan Hall, the UK’s independent reviewer of terrorism legislation, warned that demonising Israelis constitutes legal racial hatred under the Public Order Act 1986 and fuels antisemitism. He urged police to be accountable for targeting Israeli citizens and Jews, citing unchallenged pro-Palestinian chants and attacks on Israeli-owned venues. Pro-Palestine group ICJP accused him of conflating antisemitism with anti-Zionism. The debate extended to police failures—West Midlands’ ban on Maccabi Tel Aviv fans—and responses from Met commissioner Mark Rowley and antisemitism expert David Feldman.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

articles.title: Shifting offshore sandbanks pose unique navigation hazard
articles.trailText: Sandbanks can shift position during winter storms, but sonar mapping means charts can now be updated immediately
articles.summary: Offshore sandbanks like the 10-mile Goodwin Sands off Deal, Kent, near the Dover Strait, pose unique navigation hazards as winter storms drive wave energy down through 25 m of fine sand on chalk, eroding and redepositing sediment, rotating the bank anti-clockwise over decades or migrating channels rapidly—a North Sea counterpart moved 70 m in 50 days. Responsible for roughly 2,000 wrecks since 1634, they were once charted slowly via lead-line surveys and guided by dual lighthouses on South Foreland. Today, multibeam sonar enables real-time seabed mapping and immediate online chart updates.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

articles.title: Trump’s new world order: inside the 9 January Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: The repercussions of Washington’s intervention in Venezuela. Plus: the films to look out for in 2026
articles.summary: Guardian Weekly’s 9 January edition investigates Donald Trump’s audacious US military extraction of Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro—justified by alleged drug-trafficking charges but driven by oil interests—upending the postwar rules-based order. Tom Phillips reports on reactions in Caracas and neighbouring states; Dan Sabbagh details the operation; Julian Borger and Nesrine Malik question its thin legal grounds. Plus: Iran’s mass economic protests; the real prospects of de-extinction science; a psychologist’s deep dive into guilt; the decline of the French art-of-lunch; and a surge in manosphere-skewering comedy. Also, a surf-explorer’s morgue ordeal, Molly Parkin’s obituary, and immersive podcasts and galleries.

articles.title: The role one Caribbean country played in helping the US to depose Maduro
articles.trailText: Support for US action in the region seems to have laid the ground for regime change in Venezuela
articles.summary: Trinidad and Tobago’s PM Kamla Persad-Bissessar openly aligned with the Trump administration, providing US Marines with G/ATOR radar on Tobago, allowing military transits and intelligence sharing to combat trafficking. This deviation from Caricom’s ‘Zone of Peace’ stance laid groundwork for November airstrikes and January’s Maduro raid. Motivated by security concerns and ambitions to secure Venezuela’s gas fields, Persad-Bissessar bet on US backing over dialogue with Maduro. Critics warn this adversarial shift risks regional fracture, legal peril under the ICC and destabilizes Caribbean unity. Since September, US airstrikes have killed over 80 people, including Trinidadians, and other Caricom states refused similar cooperation.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

articles.title: Hard to digest: we still live in Fast Food Nation | Eric Schlosser
articles.trailText: The long read: Twenty-five years after I revealed the practices of the industrial food giants, the profits – and dangers – of mass producing meat and milk have only grown
articles.summary: 25 years after Fast Food Nation, Eric Schlosser reveals how industrial food giants and regulatory failures have worsened public health and pathogen risks. A 2024 H5N1 avian influenza outbreak in Texas mega-dairies infected cows, barn cats and dairy workers, yet USDA, FDA and CDC were hamstrung by industry pressure and state politics. Consolidation in dairy, poultry and livestock—plus low-wage immigrant labor—amplifies zoonoses and supply chain fragility. Schlosser attributes these dangers to unchecked corporate power, urging true-cost accounting, stricter oversight and systemic reform to curb externalized costs, protect workers, animals and consumers, and prevent a potential pandemic.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

articles.title: Jewish groups warned ban on Maccabi Tel Aviv fans attending match could be seen as ‘antisemitic’
articles.trailText: Minutes obtained under freedom of information laws show West Midlands police flagged concerns over decision ahead of Aston Villa match
articles.summary: FOI documents reveal that on 16 October, West Midlands police, citing intelligence of violent incidents at previous Maccabi Tel Aviv fixtures abroad and isolated antisemitic abuse, warned that banning Israeli club fans from the 6 November Europa League match at Villa Park could be ‘perceived as antisemitic’ by Jewish groups. Despite PM Starmer’s condemnation and an apology from ACC O’Hara over misstatements, no objections were raised and the ban stood. Birmingham council and the force will face Home Affairs Committee scrutiny next week; an independent governance review is under way.

articles.title: When north and south winds collide, torrential rain falls in south-east Asia
articles.trailText: The monsoon season is crucial for agriculture, making up 80% of annual rainfall, but also extremely destructive
articles.summary: Each January, south-east Asia plunges under torrential downpours—Singapore recorded over 250 mm in two days—driven by the seasonal shift of the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ), where opposing northern and southern winds meet. Known colloquially as the monsoon, this cycle carries warm, moisture-laden air inland, fueling towering cumulonimbus storms that deliver up to 80% of the region’s annual rainfall. While vital for rice cultivation and other crops, these concentrated wet spells often trigger destructive floods. By contrast, Europe’s rain falls more evenly throughout the year.

articles.title: It’s payback time: inside the 2 January Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Europe’s big, expensive state pensions crisis. Plus: The British culture boom
articles.summary: Guardian Weekly’s 2 January issue spotlights Europe’s looming state pensions crisis: ageing populations and shrinking workforces are straining pay-as-you-go systems, while voters deem pensions both unaffordable and insufficient, yet resist reforms. Jon Henley warns of a continental social contract timebomb. Plus five key features: Dan Sabbagh on Ukraine’s stalled peace prospects; Ajit Niranjan on AI’s climate footprint; Ewen MacAskill’s stark West Bank return; Martin Kettle’s uplifting kindness story; and Rachel Aroesti on the UK’s culture boom amid globalization.

articles.title: Save your new year resolutions until the spring weather arrives
articles.trailText: Feelings of overwhelm decrease as days lengthen meaning resolutions will be more successful in March
articles.summary: New year’s resolutions often fail by late February—around 80% falter—because winter’s long nights and cold temperatures reduce sunlight exposure, boost melatonin, slow metabolism, and lower energy and mood. Busy jobs and family demands persist, leaving people stressed and lacking drive for exercise or healthy diets. Clinical psychologist Kimberly Dienes recommends delaying major lifestyle changes until spring, when longer days diminish fatigue, lift spirits and improve stress resilience. Launching moderate “spring resolutions” in March—starting with realistic, incremental goals—leverages natural energy rebounds and increases the likelihood of sustainable success.

articles.title: Billionaires added record $2.2tn in wealth in 2025
articles.trailText: Just eight billionaires accounted for a quarter of the gains, led by Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Larry Ellison and Larry Page
articles.summary: The world’s 500 richest individuals added a record $2.2 trn in 2025—boosting their combined net worth to $11.9 trn—driven by Donald Trump’s 2024 election win and surging crypto, equities and metals. Eight billionaires—top among them Elon Musk ($190.3 bn gain to $622.7 bn), Larry Ellison ($57.7 bn gain to $249.8 bn), Jeff Bezos and Larry Page—accounted for a quarter of the increase. Gina Rinehart tripled her fortune to $37.7 bn via rare-earth metals, while Manuel Villar lost $12.6 bn after Golden MV shares plunged. Oxfam says these gains could lift 3.8 bn people out of poverty, highlighting policy-driven inequality.

articles.title: From the World Cup to the return of Michaela Coel, 2026 promises to excite and bring joy
articles.trailText: A very Long Wave-coded book, a landmark Nigerian film and more Black art and culture on its way in the next 12 months
articles.summary: Culture highlights for 2026 center Black diaspora joy: the expanded 48-team World Cup spotlights Ghana vs England, Senegal’s semi-final hopes and Caribbean debutant Curaçao; Antigua Carnival, Hargeisa and Calabash book fairs plus Bocas Lit Fest and Carifesta; Obama Presidential Library’s June opening in Chicago; debut novels (Terry’s Wilderness of Mirrors, Hickson-Lovence’s About to Fall Apart, McKenzie-Goddard’s Smallie); film/TV including Michaela Coel’s Mother Mary, First Day on Earth and My Father’s Shadow plus Industry S4; Bad Bunny’s Latin tour; V&A East’s Black music retrospective.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: Hopes for heavy snowfall in Chinese season of Major Snow
articles.trailText: Seasonal foods are chosen in this period with the idea that black foods are preferable for the darkest time of the year
articles.summary: From Dec 7–21, the Chinese solar term Major Snow heralds the deeper winter phase when heavy snowfall is auspicious for next year’s harvest. Festive foods include red bean porridge on Day 1 and “black foods”—sesame, beans, rice, shiitake—to match the deep darkness. It also marks large-scale pickling of meats for winter. The central five days peak in Yin energy—symbolizing stillness and the year’s turning point as tigers begin mating—before buds emerge late in the period.

While the judgment noted it was ‘conceivable’ that Anthony McGann could influence ECT decisions, it found no substantial evidence he did. Additional edits improved overall clarity. A range of other pieces—from Trump and international law to UK housing, environmental features and cultural reviews—were also amended. articles.title: How we eat and gather is central to who we are: the diaspora at Christmas
articles.trailText: Our personal and shared communal traditions across food and drink play a dominant role in festive celebrations
articles.summary: Across the African diaspora, Christmas feasts blend familial identity and communal history through distinctive dishes: in Nigeria and Ghana tables overflow with plantain, coleslaw, small chops (spring rolls, samosas, puff-puff), party jollof and fried rice, roasted turkey, chicken or beef stews, and ‘absurd’ salads bound in mayo. Black British spreads add mac & cheese, rice and peas, soups and fufu with spicy goat soup. In Brazil, cassava flour farofa seasons feijoada and turkey. Hibiscus-based drinks—sorrel, bissap, zobo or agua de Jamaica—trace back to West Africa via the slave trade, reflecting deep communal bonds.

articles.title: ‘We refuse to be afraid’: solidarity and vigilance in British Jewish community targeted by IS plot
articles.trailText: Life goes on in a vibrant Greater Manchester neighbourhood after a plan for an attack was thwarted
articles.summary: In Greater Manchester’s Kersal and Broughton Park, an Islamic State sleeper cell’s plan to “kill as many Jews as possible” was foiled with the convictions of Walid Saadaoui and Amar Hussein, but the Orthodox community responded with solidarity and resilience rather than fear. Councillor Andrew Walters and social worker Michelle Ciffer Klein emphasize cross-faith unity, grassroots support for large families, and campaigns against high living costs of kosher food and childcare. Local Shomrim patrols and the CST report heightened vigilance and intelligence-sharing, while Jewish leaders urge balanced strategies against both Islamist and far-right extremism amid growing communal cohesion.

articles.title: Cycling is changing at speed – but is Britain keeping pace?
articles.trailText: Emulating the bike-friendly highways enjoyed by our continental neighbours will take a lot more money and political will
articles.summary: Despite Team GB’s 2008 Olympic inspiration, cycle trips in England plateaued post-Covid and 2024 saw the lowest conventional bike sales this century. London bucked this trend with 1.5 million daily trips (+43 percent vs 2019), enabled by two decades of mayoral investment, congestion charges and low-traffic neighbourhoods. Shifts to ebikes, dockless hires and gravel bikes reflect safety-driven demand, yet the UK lags Europe’s subsidies—France, Germany, the Netherlands and Spain will sell over 5 million ebikes this year vs Britain’s ~150 000—and grapples with illegal high-speed e-scooters that harm cycling’s image. Experts warn only sustained political leadership and infrastructure funding can unlock mass bike commuting.

articles.title: How we hold back the tide: levees, drains and a bronze age circle of skulls
articles.trailText: Were children’s bones found at the edge of European lake settlements an attempt to appease water gods?
articles.summary: Researchers from Basel University uncovered ninth-century BC children’s skulls arranged in circles at vulnerable Bronze Age lake settlements in modern Germany and Switzerland. As flooding worsened, villagers added log palisades, stilt houses and stone-reinforced flood walls. Skull rings, redeposited years after burial, likely functioned as apotropaic magic—symbolic barriers to appease water deities. These circles appear near the final occupation phase, suggesting a last-ditch effort against rising waters. Though speculative and undocumented, the ritual highlights ancient communities’ environmental responses.

articles.title: The Crunch: the mystery of clothes shopping; children’s TV; and the rest of the best of 2025
articles.trailText: Josh and Nick pick their favourite pieces of the year, which include the best way to dice an onion, Woodside gas emissions and a voting matrix
articles.summary: In their end-of-year Crunch, Josh and Nick highlight top 2025 dataviz: The Pudding’s interactive onion-dicing font, Straits Times’s clothes-sizing guide, Our World in Data’s vaccine efficacy chart, a massive Woodside emissions square graphic; plus Nick’s picks: Washington Post’s ‘rivers in the sky’ jet-stream map, Mona Chalabi’s Gaza starvation illustration, an Australian politicians voting matrix and Lego chart, The Pudding’s conversation flow and love-song evolution analyses, and a climate-driven bird migration map. They open comments on the web version and pause over the Australian summer holidays.

articles.title: Is chorus of winter birdsong a herald of spring – or warning of climate crisis?
articles.trailText: Spells of unseasonably mild weather are prompting species such as the skylark to burst into song
articles.summary: Unseasonably mild Decembers across the UK have prompted winter birds such as robins, wrens and song thrushes—and even overwintering skylarks—to launch tentative songs outside their usual breeding season. Wrens, historically silent in winter, now sing in mild spells, a behaviour not recalled by older observers. In Somerset, mild Decembers also coax song thrushes, while a record 2015 spell yielded seven species (including dunnock, goldcrest, chiffchaff and Cetti’s warbler). These early vocalisations raise questions about shifting seasonal cues and climate risk.

articles.title: Into the void: inside the 19 December Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Trump’s erosion of the rules-based order. Plus: From climate to culture, 2025 in review
articles.summary: In its final 2025 edition, Guardian Weekly examines cracks in the global order in a year-end essay by Patrick Wintour, diagnosing a post–WWII interregnum driven by Donald Trump’s ‘mobster diplomacy’ and eroding international-law legitimacy. The issue reflects on the Sydney terror attack’s impact in Australia, celebrates inspiring everyday heroes who reshaped 2025, and reports five medical breakthroughs boosting global health. It also features reviews of 2025’s top films, music and TV, a column on rediscovering life beyond smartphones, and returns on 2 January. Gift subscriptions now available.

articles.title: How to use the holidays to stop our ‘WhatsApp aunties’ falling for AI
articles.trailText: Family members can be sweet and relentless but how can we aid our relatives in the age of new tech and device addiction
articles.summary: During festive gatherings, seize the chance to gently teach older relatives—your ‘WhatsApp aunties’—to spot AI-generated fakes. These networked women flood family chats with morning greetings, war-zone clips, celebrity reels and lengthy voice notes, now laced with manipulated videos ranging from cartoon penguins to politically charged deepfakes. Debating them can backfire—they trust online forwards like TV news and wield real influence in diaspora communities. Instead, validate content (“That’s interesting!”), then casually question its authenticity, show simple “tells” (glitches, odd shadows, blinking), and empathize with their tech anxieties. Patience and kindness, not frustration, will help them become savvier in a fast-evolving digital world.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Royal College of Emergency Medicine | Climate Investment Funds/Green Climate Fund
articles.summary: Corrections: A previous RCEM estimate was misreported as 16,600 winter deaths due to A&E delays; it covered all 2024 and long waits before admission. The November 2025 NGO report on climate aid was updated to include Climate Investment Funds/Green Climate Fund responses and an amended headline attributing findings. Other corrected pieces include articles on ex-Vodafone franchisees’ testimonies and US church nativity scenes vs ICE. Editorial feedback: guardian.readers@theguardian.com, Readers’ editor postal and voicemail contacts.

articles.title: Democrats condemn Republicans calling for Muslim ban on the heels of Australia shooting
articles.trailText: Randy Fine and Tommy Tuberville, US legislators, face backlash for Islamophobic calls to deport Muslims
articles.summary: After an Australia mass shooting, GOP Rep Randy Fine and Sen Tommy Tuberville urged a US Muslim travel ban, mass deportations of legal and illegal Muslim immigrants, and citizenship revocations, calling Islam a “cult” bent on conquest. Democrats—AOC, Patty Murray, Chris Murphy, Chuck Schumer—denounced the proposals as vile Islamophobia. CAIR labeled Tuberville the first senator deemed an “anti-Muslim bigot.” Fine doubled down on social media; Tuberville spurned Muslim community outreach. The clash underscores rising anti-Muslim rhetoric on the US right.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Christchurch massacre | Equality and Human Rights Commission
articles.summary: Corrections & clarifications: An earlier editorial misdated the Christchurch mosques massacre—2019, not 2022—and a piece on the Equality and Human Rights Commission omitted that its remit covers England, Wales and Scotland. This update also covers revisions to articles on the Bondi beach terror attack, US lawmakers’ criticism of the VA’s non-citizen database, Trump’s $1 million gold-card visa plan, Australian voters’ opposition to paid family holidays for politicians, indecent communications charges against Scotland’s Times editor, and a massive fog formation over central California. Readers can direct further corrections to the Guardian’s readers’ editor.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: US national parks
articles.summary: A correction clarifies that the new $100 charge in US national parks from 1 January applies per foreign visitor for a single standard entrance (lasting one to seven days), not per day. The notice also lists recently amended items: a column on mental health overdiagnosis, Great Britain’s new rail timetable, Thai evacuees fearing fresh Cambodia clashes, Week in Wildlife (featuring a baby echidna, a 600 lb alligator and an ‘unbearable’ bear) and Amsterdam’s Rijksmuseum Eindhoven outpost announcement. Readers can submit editorial complaints or correction requests to guardian.readers@theguardian.com, post to the Readers’ Editor at Kings Place, London N1 9GU, or voicemail +44 20 3353 4736.

articles.title: Security stepped up in UK’s Jewish communities after Bondi beach shooting
articles.trailText: Police increase patrols around synagogues and other venues as tens of thousands celebrate Hanukah
articles.summary: After 12 died in an antisemitic shooting at Sydney’s Bondi Beach, the Met and Police Scotland upped patrols around synagogues and Jewish venues during Hanukah, consulting community leaders and the Community Security Trust. Despite no specific UK threat, forces cite “heightened concern.” PM Keir Starmer called the attack “sickening,” King Charles and Queen Camilla expressed grief, and Jewish charity chief Dave Rich warned a “wave of anti-Jewish hatred” persists. The Board of Deputies urges stronger, coordinated action against terrorism and antisemitism.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: The Salt Path | Christmas tree
articles.summary: Corrections and clarifications: Tomorrow’s pre-printed What’s On supplement mislabels bestselling memoir The Salt Path as being written by ‘authors’ instead of sole author Raynor Winn. A 1990 tree photo described as an in-store John Lewis Christmas tree was actually taken in Liverpool’s former Lewis’s department store. Other recent amendments cover: the planned cancellation of UK ‘zombie’ electricity projects to speed grid connections; Eurovision winner Nemo’s pledge to return his trophy over Israel’s 2026 entry; Ofgem’s early investment approval for three UK electricity ‘superhighways’; and Brittany Higgins’ bankruptcy ruling after losing her defamation case to Linda Reynolds. Readers can send editorial complaints and correction requests to guardian.readers@theguardian.com or write to the Readers’ editor at Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Richard Walker | Canadian head of government
articles.summary: Corrections to a Dec 11 piece clarify that Richard Walker, Iceland's executive chair, has never donated to Labour (though he publicly backed it in 2024 after years supporting Conservatives). It also notes Canada elects a prime minister, not a president. Additionally amended articles include features on Sondheim's Into the Woods, rising parcel thefts, UK household spending cuts per Barclays, and photos of dinosaurs, nuclear reactors and vintage cars. Readers may submit corrections or complaints to guardian.readers@theguardian.com, mail to Readers' Editor at Kings Place, London N1 9GU, or voicemail at +44 20 3353 4736.

articles.title: Endoscopy finds Neanderthal noses not as adapted to the cold as expected
articles.trailText: Study on skull of Altamura Man could be blow to adaptation theories about Neanderthals and their extinction
articles.summary: Nasal endoscopy of the Altamura Man skull, embedded in Italy’s Lamalunga cave, reveals no bony convolutions in the enlarged Neanderthal nasal cavity once believed to warm Ice Age air. University of Perugia researchers conclude Neanderthal noses lacked these adaptations despite a larger aperture. Scrapping this key cold‐air conditioning hypothesis shifts focus to other strategies—such as elevated metabolism—and deepens the puzzle of why Neanderthals vanished if their respiratory physiology rivalled modern humans’ in both cold and warming climates.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Kanal museum, Brussels
articles.summary: Guardian corrections 10 Dec 2025: The new Brussels Kanal museum will surpass Tate Modern’s original (pre-2016) size, not its extended footprint. Other amended stories include: politics (Linda Reynolds on Brittany Higgins), film (Daniel Day-Lewis defends Paul Dano vs Tarantino), education (Hungarian teacher Pride event charges), law (Scottish nurse tribunal ruling), business (ex-Vodafone franchisee mental-health crisis), tech (viewer-tracking digital billboards), health (ADHD diagnosis rise), science (seismic-wave soil checks), and AI’s role in democracy. Send corrections: guardian.readers@theguardian.com or Readers’ editor, Kings Place, London.

articles.title: Australia’s social media ban: inside the 12 December Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Will the world follow suit? Plus: Best books of 2025
articles.summary: In response to eSafety research revealing that 70% of 10–15-year-olds encounter online harm—misogyny, violence, disordered eating, suicide—Australia’s government enacted the world’s first under-16 social media ban on 12 December. From Wednesday millions of teens were locked out as eSafety commissioner Julie Inman Grant seeks ‘friction’ to curb big tech’s extractive impact. While policymakers in other countries watch closely, critics question enforcement among tech-savvy youths and warn disabled users will lose support. Guardian Weekly’s Josh Taylor examines the law’s origins and mechanics; Doosie Morris shares teens’ first-hand reactions.

articles.title: A tribute to resilience: what we can learn from the splendour of Accra Cultural Week
articles.trailText: Ghana’s capital is a party and entertainment hub but members of the diaspora would do well to experience its spectacular art scene
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine’s farewell Long Wave dispatch details her first visit to Accra Cultural Week, centering on Jamestown’s resilience through Serge Attukwei Clottey’s [Dis]Appearing Rituals and afrogallonism, which repurposes yellow jerrycans into gold mosaics. She explores Jamestown’s Ga fishing heritage and Tabom community architecture—Portuguese-built Fort Vicentia (1660) and British lighthouse (1871)—and notes vibrant funeral posters and beach installations. Clottey’s work highlights environmental costs of fast-fashion waste. Additional highlights include Reginald Sylvester II’s Tema-welded sculptures and the Yaa Asantewaa Art prize exhibitions by Denyse Gawu-Mensah and Theresah Ankomah. Amid winter party tourism, Accra’s cultural season proves a lasting artistic force.

articles.title: ‘The 0.001%’: a quick visual breakdown of the world’s wealthiest people
articles.trailText: About 56,000 people control three times as much wealth as half of humanity. Here’s one way to illustrate that
articles.summary: An inequality report finds 56,000 people – the global 0.001% – each with hundreds of millions in assets, averaging nearly €1 billion. Together they’d fit into a 56,000-seat stadium yet control three times the wealth of the poorest 2.8 billion adults (the bottom 50%), while the top 10% own 75% of global assets. Their wealth is rising at almost 5% annually vs. 3.4% for the bottom half. To illustrate the gap, it would take 50,000 such stadiums to seat the poorest half, whose combined wealth is only one-third that of this ultra-rich cohort.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: NHS polling
articles.summary: Correction: an earlier Journal article claiming ‘barely a quarter of Britons’ knew waiting lists fell under Labour’s first year used England-only polling for the Health Foundation, not UK-wide figures. Other recent amendments span pieces on environmental harm from food and fossil fuels, UAE-backed forces in South Yemen, US veterans affairs sharing immigration data, the Crown Estate probe, Australian teens on the social media ban, Golden Globe nominations, a 15-year-old’s Snapchat age-check bypass, young New Zealand farmers and Nick Fuentes’ role in a US Republican civil war. Readers can send editorial complaints or correction requests to the Guardian’s readers’ editor via email, post or voicemail.

articles.title: Retired greyhounds to continue to be rehomed overseas despite ‘distressing and sometimes fatal’ outcomes
articles.trailText: Independent review calls for sweeping restructure of NSW’s greyhound racing industry but government rejects key recommendations
articles.summary: An independent review led by Lea Drake found New South Wales’s practice of rehoming retired greyhounds overseas is “distressing and sometimes fatal” after six dogs died in US transport or preparation. The NSW government rejected calls to halt exporting and to suspend racing if Greyhound Racing NSW (GRNSW) misses new track standards deadlines, instead requiring only “where possible” domestic rehoming, heightened GRNSW oversight and death reporting. It also refused caps on births or a statutory inspector. Animal advocates condemned the response as inadequate.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Sue Gray
articles.summary: This corrections notice clarifies that in the 4 December article on Starmer’s peers, Sue Gray was wrongly captioned as ‘another likely appointee’; she was in fact named in his December 2024 list and took her seat as Baroness Gray of Tottenham in February 2025. It also lists recent amendments to articles on a Co Offaly murder inquiry, a UN report on Māori rights, the January 6 pipe-bomb suspect, a US student jailed for chicken theft and the UK-EU youth mobility scheme. For corrections, contact guardian.readers@theguardian.com, Readers’ Editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU or voicemail +44 (0)20 3353 4736.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Halo TikTok channel | Your Party vote
articles.summary: Guardian issues corrections clarifying that a motor-racing TikTok post attributed to Sky Sports’ Halo channel was a parody on another account; the vote against Your Party’s collective leadership was 48.4%, not 48.6%, and the online article’s For The Many tally was 23.52%, not 25.23%. Additional amendments cover US neo-Nazi leader reprisals, release of a boat strike video, £2m homeowners, the Dutch king on slavery, and a Myanmar junta crony’s FIFA role. Readers can send corrections to guardian.readers@theguardian.com or write to the Readers’ editor.

articles.title: ‘Don’t say we didn’t warn you’: Hong Kong foreign media told not to cause trouble after fire
articles.trailText: Beijing security agency accuses international journalists of disregarding facts and smearing government
articles.summary: On Dec 6, Beijing’s Hong Kong Office for Safeguarding National Security summoned senior foreign journalists – including from the New York Times and AFP – over critical coverage of the Nov 26 Wang Fuk Court apartment fire that killed 159, accusing them of ignoring facts, smearing government relief efforts and colluding with 'anti-China' forces. The OSNS statement cited no examples, refused questions, and warned reporters to 'not cross the legal red line' or face consequences, part of broader press freedom erosion under the 2020 national security law ahead of Sunday’s revamped 'patriots-only' election.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Summit location | Weirdos Book Club | Fools Gold
articles.summary: The Guardian issues corrections: the peace talks story wrongly stated Trump planned a Putin summit in Bucharest, it’s Budapest; Weirdos Book Club co-host is Sara Pascoe, not Rachel Parris; and the Stone Roses single “Fools Gold” was a standalone release, not on their debut album. It also lists recent fixes on wealth inheritance, UBS report on Swiss gold and Rolex gifts to Trump, fashion’s sheer skirts, Booker T & the MGs guitarist Steve Cropper’s death, EV range tests in Australia, a review of mental health claim processes, and the bird theory relationship feature. Contact readers’ editor for further corrections.

articles.title: ‘Three sheets to the wind’: how everyday phrases blew in from the sea
articles.trailText: From ‘all at sea’ to ‘by and large’, windy weather has had quite an impact on the English language
articles.summary: This article traces how maritime wind jargon became everyday English. Familiar terms like “all at sea” and “even keel” have clear nautical roots, but lesser-known expressions began as sailor shorthand for wind tactics: “overbearing” described a ship with superior sail area, “bear down” meant to approach with the wind behind, and “veering” (clockwise shift) versus “backing” (anticlockwise) came from French virer. “By and large” originally referred to alternating between sailing close-hauled and downwind, now meaning generally. These idioms have seamlessly crossed from ship decks into common speech.

articles.title: The Crunch: voting in Victoria; gambling in a crypto casino; and the sex lives of gen Z
articles.trailText: Victoria is the last state still using group voting tickets to elect its upper house – and now there are calls to abolish them
articles.summary: The Crunch this week examines Victoria’s group voting tickets – with the electoral matters committee urging their abolition and new ballot reforms – alongside ABC’s account of a gambler losing over US$180k in a crypto casino. It highlights Reuters’ visual story on how climate-driven disasters have pushed 100,000 more California homes into non-profit ‘last resort’ insurers, JP Morgan’s finding that tech must generate an extra US$650bn/year for 10% AI returns, a distribution-focused analysis of English readability, and Mona Chalabi’s data-rich charts on American Gen Z’s sex lives from hookups to monogamy and the politics of intimacy.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Sir Tom Stoppard obituary
articles.summary: Corrections clarify that Sir Tom Stoppard’s grandparents, though deported to Terezín in German-occupied Czechoslovakia, actually died in the Riga ghetto (paternal) and at Auschwitz (maternal). His play The Hard Problem premiered in 2015, not 2006. Other amended items include “Trump’s night of 160 posts on Truth Social fuels debate about US president’s stamina.” Readers can send editorial complaints and correction requests to guardian.readers@theguardian.com, to the Readers’ editor at Kings Place, London N1 9GU, or leave a voicemail at +44 20 3353 4736.

articles.title: Record numbers becoming billionaires through inheritance, UBS report finds
articles.trailText: Swiss bank says bequests made 91 people billionaires, while overall number jumped from 2,682 in 2024 to 2,919 this year
articles.summary: UBS reports that inheritance created 91 new billionaires globally in the year to April, receiving $298bn, pushing the total to 2,919, up from 2,682 in 2024. Self-made billionaires rose by 196 with $386.5bn. UBS warns of a $5.9tn multi-year wealth transfer over 15 years, led by the US, India, France, Germany and Switzerland. Governments from Switzerland to the UK and EU debates on wealth taxes intensify amid calls for levies on fortunes over tens of millions.

articles.title: Garden ponds provide vital habitats – and a revival is under way in Britain
articles.trailText: Even tiny ponds can create biodiversity hotspots, as well as helping out during heatwaves and heavy rain
articles.summary: A grassroots revival of garden ponds is under way in Britain, where even tiny waterbodies can create biodiversity hotspots, hosting frogs, hedgehogs, and increased bird life. Research by Lucy Clarke et al. shows Britain lost 58% of its Severn Vale ponds since the 1900s, increasing inter-pond distances by 25m, mirroring global declines driven by intensive farming and urban growth. Renewed interest recognizes ponds large and small as essential habitats that buffer climate extremes—cooling during heatwaves, slowing heavy-rain runoff, recharging groundwater and alleviating drain overload.

articles.title: Hong Kong warns ‘external forces’ working to exploit apartment fire, as death toll rises to 159
articles.trailText: Police say number of dead may still be revised as ‘suspected human bones’ found during search require forensic testing
articles.summary: Beijing and Hong Kong officials have accused unspecified “external forces” of seeking to exploit last week’s blaze at Wang Fuk Court—which has killed at least 159 people and is the city’s deadliest residential fire in 75 years—for political disruption. Investigations focus on flammable renovation materials and malfunctioning alarms, prompting 21 arrests on manslaughter and related charges. Development Secretary Bernadette Linn ordered the removal of scaffolding netting on about 200 buildings. Meanwhile, three people have been detained under national security laws for petitions demanding accountability. An independent review committee is probing the disaster amid ongoing forensic tests and victim identification.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Cryptic crossword No 29,868 | Robert F Kennedy Jr
articles.summary: Corrections: Cryptic crossword No 29,868’s 12-across clue amended—replace “nevertheless catches” with “by chance catching” for the correct vowel set. An America section misnamed Robert F Kennedy Jr as his late father. Other updates cover David Lammy’s plan to dilute planned jury-trial reforms; arrests after an ICE raid in NYC; a high court appeal to lift the Palestine Action ban; risks from hidden UK/Europe landfills; our top 20 songs of 2025; and Toto’s role at PM Albanese’s wedding. Readers can send complaints to guardian.readers@theguardian.com or to the Readers’ editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU.

articles.title: After the Hong Kong inferno: inside the 5 December Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Power, corruption and negligence. Plus: The rise of extremist Buddhism
articles.summary: Guardian Weekly’s 5 December issue leads with Helen Davidson and Shanshan Kao’s cover story on Hong Kong’s deadliest fire in decades at Wang Fuk Court, which killed at least 151 residents amid allegations of corruption, negligent building materials and a political culture that stifles public accountability—drawing parallels with London’s Grenfell Tower disaster. Five essential reads include: Patrick Wintour on Europe’s quest to constrain Russia without US backing; Jessica Elgot on how Rachel Reeves’s fate could determine Keir Starmer’s tenure; Sonia Faleiro on extremist Buddhism in Southeast Asia; Nesrine Malik on Israel’s widening offensives; and Xan Brooks’s interview with Ethan Hawke and Richard Linklater about their new film Blue Moon.

articles.title: Illustrating the ‘postcolonial experience’: 40 years of Peepal Tree Press
articles.trailText: As the publisher celebrates an important milestone, we chart its journey from an ‘expensive hobby’ to an international household name
articles.summary: Peepal Tree Press, founded in Leeds in 1985 by Jeremy Poynting after his PhD on Caribbean writing, has spent 40 years championing Caribbean and diaspora authors. Starting as an ‘expensive hobby’ with a garage printing press and sustained by Arts Council funding and personal sacrifice, it published Booker winner Bernardine Evaristo’s debut and nurtured talents like Roger Robinson and Monique Roffey despite mainstream rejections. Unique for its straight submissions and writer incubation, Peepal Tree critiques the limited, trauma-focused Black narratives embraced by major houses and urges innovation in postcolonial storytelling and the novel form itself.

articles.title: Scientists uncover surprise origin of wispy cirrus clouds
articles.trailText: These delicate cloud systems appear to be seeded by massive atmospheric waves thousands of miles away
articles.summary: New satellite-based computer analysis, reported in AGU Advances, reveals that “in-situ” cirrus clouds are seeded not spontaneously but by massive atmospheric waves triggered by distant storm systems thousands of miles away. These waves cross the equator, alter upper-atmosphere temperature profiles, and induce high-altitude ice crystal formation. Distinct from anvil-outflow cirrus, this mechanism suggests shifting storm patterns could alter cirrus distribution and reinforce their net warming effect by trapping infrared radiation, with important implications for future climate modeling.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Nvidia | Villa San Giovanni ferry
articles.summary: The Guardian issues corrections: Nvidia’s valuation is $4.3tn, not $3.4tn; the Intercity train to Sicily remains on rails aboard the Villa San Giovanni ferry. Other corrected stories include Australian Medicare safety-net fee subsidies, Tasmania’s stalled AFL stadium, a Sugababes–Sophie Ellis-Bextor–Wolf Alice trans-rights charity concert, Lord Rothermere’s rising media power and an Italian mayor’s Pavarotti statue apology. Editorial complaints can be sent to guardian.readers@theguardian.com, mailed to Readers’ Editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, or left by voicemail at +44 (0)20 3353 4736.

articles.title: The labour of love breathing life back into palawa kani – the lost language of Lutruwita
articles.trailText: Aboriginal children are being born in Tasmania today knowing the sounds of their ancient tongue. They are the first to do so for 150 years
articles.summary: After Tasmanian Aboriginal numbers plummeted to under 100 by the 1830s, the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre spent over 30 years reconstructing palawa kani from colonial diaries, wax-cylinder recordings of Fanny Smith and linguist Terry Crowley’s work. June Sculthorpe, Daisy Allan, Theresa Sainty and colleagues crafted a standardized orthography, age-specific language modules and a digital placename map. For the first time in 150 years, Palawa children are born into and taught this revived tongue, symbolizing enduring resilience, activism and cultural sovereignty in Lutruwita/Tasmania.

articles.title: Hong Kong responds to disaster differently from Beijing – but the gulf is narrowing
articles.trailText: Independent inquiry into fire and media questions to leader would not happen in mainland China, but crackdown on dissent has begun
articles.summary: After Hong Kong’s deadliest fire killed 151 at Wang Fuk Court, Chief Exec John Lee announced a judge-led independent inquiry—an approach unthinkable in CCP-run mainland China but whose autonomy critics say is already compromised post-2019 security crackdowns. Thirteen arrests for suspected manslaughter have been made, yet no official accountability. Sunday’s “patriots-only” LegCo election—a vote many see boycotting as one of the few safe protests—risks record low turnout. Arrests over petitions and rare unscripted press scrutiny contrast starkly with mainland’s censored media and staged politics, underscoring both Hong Kong’s unique freedoms and their ongoing erosion.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Government expenditure chart | Christopher Mullan obituary
articles.summary: Corrections: Guardian’s government expenditure chart mislabelled £400 bn ‘income tax’ instead of ‘social protection’ and omitted a £62 bn public order and safety item. Christopher Mullan obituary now correctly names his mother’s maiden surname as McCullagh. The notice also lists other updated stories—from GB News contributor ties and Met police ‘Casey 2’ inquiry to Budget 2025 analysis and obituaries—and invites readers to send complaints or correction requests via email, post, or voicemail.

articles.title: The Australian school spearheading an Indigenous language revival
articles.trailText: At Gumbaynggirr Giingana Freedom School – the first Aboriginal bilingual school in New South Wales – success is judged by an unconventional metric: happiness
articles.summary: At Gumbaynggirr Giingana Freedom School (GGFS), NSW's first Aboriginal bilingual school, students start day with Gumbaynggirr songs and dance. Launched by the Bularri Muurlay Nyanggan Aboriginal Corporation, GGFS immerses its 15 growing to 95 Indigenous pupils in daily language classes and immersion in Gumbaynggirr. Driven by cultural pride and “happiness” rather than standard metrics, it records 88.5% attendance and above‐average Naplan scores for Indigenous students. Families relocate hours, noting transformed confidence and identity in children like Darruy Briggs. Backed by the Muurrbay Aboriginal Language Co-operative’s revival effort, GGFS aspires to full immersion parity with New Zealand’s Māori kura kaupapa.

articles.title: Hong Kong apartment fires: have you been affected?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people in Hong Kong who have been impacted by the apartment fires
articles.summary: Last week’s inferno at Hong Kong’s Wang Fuk Court complex—home to roughly 5,000 residents—has killed at least 146 people with around 200 still missing. Alleged faulty renovation work is under scrutiny, and 13 suspects have been arrested on manslaughter charges amid resident anger over previous safety lapses and heavy-handed national security law detentions of civilians demanding accountability. Citizens have left memorial tributes. The Guardian invites firsthand accounts from those affected via an encrypted online form or Secure Messaging; IP addresses are logged externally—consider privacy before sharing.

articles.title: Hong Kong arrests 13 on suspicion of manslaughter over apartment fires
articles.trailText: Authorities face growing criticism for detaining at least two civilians who have called for accountability
articles.summary: Authorities in Hong Kong have arrested 13 people, including directors and an engineering consultant from the firm renovating Tai Po’s Wang Fuk Court estate, on suspicion of manslaughter after a fire killed 151 residents and left around 40 missing. Officials allege non–fire-retardant scaffolding mesh was hidden to cut costs; tests found 7 of 20 samples non-compliant. The anti-corruption commission is probing prior safety violations and enforcement lapses amid public anger. Separately, national security police detained two civilians over an online petition demanding victim support and accountability, sparking backlash over restricted dissent.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Lord Paul | Helsing factory
articles.summary: An obituary of Lord Paul (12 Nov, Journal p7) misattributed his 1998–2001 service to the Bank of England’s MPC; he served on the House of Lords select committee on the MPC. A report that defence-tech firm Helsing was building a factory in Portsmouth was incorrect: the facility opened in Plymouth. Other recent amendments include articles on women in free jazz and anti-abortion activist Joanna Howe at the University of Adelaide. Editorial complaints: guardian.readers@theguardian.com, Readers’ editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU; voicemail +44 (0)20 3353 4736.

articles.title: At Boobera Lagoon, I dip my toes into learning a long-dormant language
articles.trailText: I’ve travelled to my grandfather’s tiny home town of Toomelah to discover how words, stories, country and culture intersect
articles.summary: Traveling to his grandfather’s land near Toomelah, the author had learned basic Gamilaraay words like yaama and yinarr via apps, yet felt disconnected until joining Gomeroi elder Carl McGrady at Boobera Lagoon, a sacred waterhole. He explores Old and New Toomelah mission sites, hears stories of displacement under the Aborigines Protection Act, and witnesses local revival of language in schools and community workshops. At the lagoon, Carl recounts the Garriya creation myth as the author dips toes in the water, embodying “yarragaa” – the warm wind of renewal marking his cultural rebirth.

articles.title: ‘In the presence of evil’: Manchester synagogue attack survivor on the day that shook British Jews
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Shot as he barricaded the synagogue, Yoni Finlay describes the assault – and the climate that allowed it to happen
articles.summary: On Yom Kippur morning at Heaton Park synagogue in Manchester, father of four Yoni Finlay led dawn prayers when extremist Jihad al-Shamie attacked, fatally stabbing Adrian Daulby and Melvin Cravitz. Finlay helped barricade doors, was shot by police intervening after al-Shamie pledged allegiance to ISIS. Seven weeks later he bears physical and psychological scars, expressing survivor’s guilt and condemning the rising antisemitism that preceded the assault. He calls on government and media to address hatred’s root causes rather than fortifying communal gates, urging compassion, unity and concrete action against antisemitism.

articles.title: A Black Georgia community uprooted in 1942 still fights to go home
articles.trailText: US descendants of Harris Neck’s Gullah Geechee families seek the return of ancestral land seized for a wartime airfield
articles.summary: Harris Neck, a thriving Black Gullah Geechee enclave on Georgia’s coast, was cleared in 1942 under eminent domain for a WWII airfield, displacing 75 families. Descendants formed two advocacy groups—the Harris Neck Land Trust (2005) and Direct Descendants of Harris Neck Community (2019)—to lobby for return of 500 acres, rebuild homesteads, school and a cultural center. They host annual commemorations, site tours with QR-history codes, and seek federal land transfer via local resolutions and MOUs with US Fish and Wildlife Service. Despite incremental gains and opposition to reparations, families remain hopeful for restoration of ancestral land.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Ronni Ancona | Prisoner 951 | This is Christmas
articles.summary: Corrections: Ronni Ancona studied at Central Saint Martins then University College London (not Edinburgh College of Art), and The Big Impression sketch show ran until 2004 (not 2003). Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was not a producer of the BBC drama Prisoner 951. Chris Foggin’s film This Is Christmas was released in 2022 (not last year). Other recently amended articles include a boudoir photography feature and a Christmas gift guide for swimmers. Readers can send corrections to guardian.readers@theguardian.com or write to the Readers’ editor at Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU.

articles.title: Rescue efforts end at Hong Kong tower block fire as death toll reaches 128
articles.trailText: About 200 people are still unaccounted for, say officials, as fire chief confirms no alarms went off in any of the eight towers
articles.summary: The fire in Tai Po’s Wang Fuk Court high-rise began Wednesday, killing 128 and leaving about 200 unaccounted. Rescue operations ended after recovering 108 bodies. No alarms sounded in any of the eight towers, prompting enforcement actions against responsible contractors. The blaze spread via polystyrene foam on scaffolding netting, with temperatures reaching 500C. Hong Kong’s anti-corruption watchdog arrested eight engineering and scaffolding contractors; three more are detained. Identification efforts continue amid reported missing Indonesian and Filipino domestic helpers. Investigators expect three to four weeks to gather evidence. The disaster spurred calls to mandate flame-retardant materials in construction codes.

articles.title: How the Hong Kong fire unfolded – visual guide
articles.trailText: Fire in densely packed group of 31-storey tower blocks home to thousands quickly spread on bamboo scaffolding
articles.summary: At 2.52pm on Wednesday a blaze broke out on bamboo scaffolding around Wang Cheong House in Tai Po, rapidly engulfing seven of the eight 31-storey towers at Wang Fuk Court. Highly flammable construction netting and polystyrene foam aided the spread across 1,969 flats housing about 4,800 residents. Over 200 fire trucks and 100 ambulances responded, but crews struggled to reach top floors. More than 100 people died, around 200 remain missing and dozens were injured, including firefighters. No fire alarms activated. Officials suspect negligent contractors installed substandard mesh and foam, and have launched enforcement actions alongside a HK$300m relief fund. Rescue operations formally ended Friday, with evidence collection expected to take weeks.

articles.title: Hong Kong community groups deliver aid to survivors of Wang Fuk Court fire
articles.trailText: Volunteers that emerged during the pro-democracy protests regroup to help those affected by the blaze
articles.summary: Hong Kong grassroots community groups have mobilised restaurants, churches and gyms in Tai Po into shelters, delivering food, clothing and information to survivors of the Wang Fuk Court fire that killed at least 128 and left hundreds missing. Volunteers used crowd-sourced web apps and interactive maps to track residents, missing persons and supply stations, while encrypted Telegram channels coordinate drivers and list urgent needs. Fundraising platforms, including a HKD 300 million government support fund, and legal volunteers offering tenancy and employment advice in multiple languages have sprung up. Questions over bamboo scaffolding, flammable Styrofoam, absent alarms and contractor Prestige—whose staff face manslaughter charges—fuel scrutiny.

articles.title: Hong Kong police say unsafe scaffolding and foam may have spread fire that killed at least 94
articles.trailText: Three construction employees arrested as firefighters battle to reach trapped people, with many still missing
articles.summary: Hong Kong police say unsafe bamboo scaffolding and non–fire-retardant foam used during renovation of the Wang Fuk Court housing estate in Tai Po likely fueled a blaze that killed at least 94, injured 76 (including 11 firefighters) and left scores missing. Firefighters still struggle to reach upper floors across four towers; one building remained untouched. Authorities arrested two directors and an engineering consultant of contractor Prestige Construction amid allegations of gross negligence and are probing breaches of fire-safety ordinances. Chief Executive John Lee reported 279 unaccounted for. Comparisons drawn to 2017 Grenfell Tower disaster.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Jury trials proposal
articles.summary: The Guardian clarifies that its 26 November report on scrapping jury trials for all but the most serious offences—citing a crown court backlog of 78,000—applies solely to England and Wales, as criminal justice is devolved in Scotland and Northern Ireland. It also notes recent corrections to features on Tom Heaton at Manchester United, European military mobility, legal actions involving James Comey and a US senator, and Turning Point USA’s 2028 strategy. Readers can send complaints or requests to guardian.readers@theguardian.com, mail to Readers’ editor at Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU, or leave voicemail at +44 (0)20 3353 4736.

articles.title: Hong Kong fire: what we know so far
articles.trailText: Dozens are confirmed dead, with hundreds more missing, after fire broke out and spread quickly via bamboo scaffolding
articles.summary: At least 94 people, including one firefighter, have died and 76 are injured after a blaze tore through the bamboo-scaffolded Wang Fuk Court in Tai Po’s eight 32-storey towers on 27 Nov. Around 250 remain missing and more than 900 have been evacuated to shelters. Hong Kong’s chief executive John Lee says fires are under control in seven towers. Three construction executives were arrested for alleged gross negligence; police, backed by 26 rescue teams, are probing the roles of bamboo scaffolding and exterior cladding. Xi Jinping offered condolences.

articles.title: In air thick with acrid smoke, people in Hong Kong are reeling and angry
articles.trailText: As apartment complex still blazes more than 24 hours after fire began, police suspect cause is owing to ‘grossly negligent’ action
articles.summary: More than 24 hours after a fire broke out at Wang Fuk Court, an eight-tower residential complex in Tai Po, Hong Kong, flames still raged in seven of the 31-storey blocks, sending acrid smoke across the district. Investigators suspect gross negligence—unsafe bamboo scaffolding and foam insulation used in long-delayed renovations—contributed to the blaze’s rapid spread. At least 65 people, including a firefighter, have died; dozens are injured, roughly 55 rescued and over 250 missing. Neighbours and volunteers have rallied at shelters, providing essentials and emotional support. Three construction workers were arrested, and the ICAC has launched a taskforce amid public anger over lax safety standards.

articles.title: NHS doctor suspended over alleged antisemitic social media posts
articles.trailText: Rahmeh Aladwan barred from practising for 15 months pending inquiry amid claims she ‘celebrated terrorist acts’
articles.summary: Dr Rahmeh Aladwan, a British-Palestinian trauma and orthopaedics trainee, has been suspended for 15 months by the MPTS pending a GMC inquiry. She faces allegations of antisemitic social media posts justifying terrorism, misusing Holocaust and Nazi imagery, promoting conspiracy theories and expressing support for proscribed groups including Hamas. Complaints from the Jewish Medical Association UK and others cite posts calling Royal Free hospital a “Jewish supremacy cesspit” and doxing colleagues. The tribunal cited risks to patient confidence; a review is due in six months. Aladwan denies hate speech, claiming legitimate political debate, while the health secretary calls for regulator reform.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: Can you really hear the wind?
articles.trailText: Some would argue airflow is silent, and that only the objects in its way give rise to vortex shedding or sough
articles.summary: Wind's 'sound' arises not from silent airflow itself but from turbulence—vortex shedding—around objects: branches and leaves produce psithurism or sough (white-noise-like mix of frequencies), pine needles a higher-pitched hiss, building edges Aeolian tones (howls akin to blowing over a bottle). Resonance can set wires humming like Aeolian harp strings, and even our ear structure distorts external airflow into the sounds we attribute to wind. In essence, wind is silent; all we hear is its interaction with objects.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Airstrikes on Iran | Birmingham bin strike
articles.summary: Two clarifications: Israeli airstrikes, not US, killed over 1,000 Iranians in June, while US strikes on Iranian nuclear sites caused no casualties; agency staff in the Birmingham bin strike were already council employees. Other corrected pieces cover: a Chilean reserve blizzard, shifting Beatles narratives, the sale of LA’s Stahl house, workplace gender crises, New Zealand’s feral cat cull, Australian marsupial conservation, shipwreck-based fish restoration and menstrual synchrony. Readers can send complaints or correction requests via email, post or voicemail to the Guardian Readers’ Editor.

articles.title: Cop30 and the climate fight: inside the 28 November Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: Turning climate talk into action. Plus: Is Palantir’s Alex Karp the world’s scariest CEO?
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, Brazil, after near-walkouts and last-minute brinkmanship, delegations won a weak consensus on phasing out fossil fuels. Despite a US pro-coal presidency, right-wing populism, Ukraine and Gaza conflicts and economic uncertainty, environment editor Fiona Harvey and Jonathan Watts dissect the flawed deal and geopolitical headwinds. Plus Guardian Weekly highlights: US-Russian Ukraine peace plan (Harding & Sauer), Trump’s Gulf tilt (Borger), Palantir CEO Alex Karp’s surveillance ambitions (Rose), Catholic church vs Trump (Tisdall), and Edmund de Waal’s new ceramics show.

articles.title: ‘Ignoring minorities is our original sin’: the complex roots of Nigeria’s security crisis
articles.trailText: Criminal exploitation, economic opportunism and religious persecution are all factors in a broader picture of insecurity
articles.summary: In Nigeria, security crisis stems from historical marginalisation of ethnic and religious minorities driving violence in the middle belt. Escalating abductions (300 schoolchildren in Niger state), mass killings in Benue and live-streamed church attacks highlight religious persecution by Fulani-derived Sharia elites against Christians and heterodox Muslims. Herder-farmer clashes, fueled by climate change, criminal exploitation and desertification, have seen armed Fulani herders expand south. Centralised Abuja control, lack of state police and poor intelligence create ungoverned spaces for Boko Haram and bandits. Chronic data gaps obscure true scale. Ignoring minorities remains Nigeria’s original sin. Global spotlight (Trump’s invasion threat, Nicki Minaj’s UN address) hasn’t addressed these root causes.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Sayce review | Wordwheel
articles.summary: The Guardian corrects that the Sayce review considered but did not recommend compensation for those affected by the carer’s allowance scandal, and that Monday’s Wordwheel answer was “nightlife,” not “attenuate.” It also lists recent amendments to articles including the Civilisations TV review, DPD delivery‐driver sackings, a legal complaint against Serbia’s president, an NSW children’s incarceration loophole, Bach’s lost organ works, the 2025 BirdLife Australia photography awards, Ukraine’s first elite sumo champion, the US affordability crisis, CSIRO job cuts raising extinction concerns, and Dick Van Dyke’s James Bond refusal. articles.title: As I write my last column, the facts on climate crisis speak for themselves
articles.trailText: Since 1995, when the first Cop was held, carbon levels have increased from 360.67 parts per million to 426.68 parts now
articles.summary: Columnist reflects on three decades of UN climate summits, from the inaugural COP in Berlin 1995—when CO2 stood at 360.67 ppm and German environment minister Angela Merkel chaired her first major conference—to today’s 426.68 ppm, well above the 350 ppm safety threshold. Despite repeated pledges at Kyoto, Paris and annual COP meetings, greenhouse emissions continue rising. The author, marking their final column, contends that this unrelenting data trajectory, unchanged by calls for optimism, starkly illustrates the escalating climate emergency.

articles.title: The Crunch: the climate crisis is expensive; it’s Ashes time; and what a Cop out
articles.trailText: Want to get this in your inbox every fortnight? Sign up for The Crunch here.
articles.summary: This edition of The Crunch examines the true economic stakes of climate action in Australia, showing that delaying net-zero could slash GDP by 9% (hundreds of billions) by 2050 compared with a transition scenario; celebrates Ashes cricket with a focus on Nathan Lyon’s spin dominance, a quiz and rankings of all-time top players; dissects BJP’s landslide victory in Bihar using demographic and geographic maps; surveys COP30 charts revealing global emissions still exceed 1.5°C pathways despite some progress in China and 35 countries; and highlights an interactive cluster visualization of trans media coverage.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: UK living standards analysis | Unix
articles.summary: Guardian issues corrections clarifying that a published analysis labeling the current government “on course to be the worst for living standards on record” actually referred to the previous administration; Unix was mischaracterized as a coding language but is an operating system. Additional corrected articles include investigations into Jamal Khashoggi’s fate; Trump’s remarks recalling the journalist’s murder; a New Jersey man jailed again after a Trump commutation; Elon Musk’s Grokipedia white nationalist content; Silver splitters on divorced women’s happiness; and Kashmiri women birthing solo. Readers can send corrections to guardian.readers@theguardian.com or the Readers’ Editor via post or voicemail.

articles.title: Easterly winds and clear skies are cue for charismatic waxwings to cross to UK
articles.trailText: While the autumn bird migration is mostly over, look out for waxwings, hard-to-spot woodcocks and even wood pigeons
articles.summary: By November UK autumn migration wanes but weather-driven movements of waxwings, woodcocks and wood pigeons persist. High waxwing numbers in southern Scandinavia can be propelled by easterly winds and clear skies to cross the North Sea, arriving in noisy east coast flocks feeding on berries. Secretive woodcocks likewise migrate on clear nights, peaking in November, while large wood pigeon flocks—e.g., 231,000 over Portskewett—may cross the Channel to overwinter in Europe.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Dynamo Moscow | Jim Laker
articles.summary: The Guardian issues corrections to a Europa League analysis, clarifying Dynamo Moscow—not Kyiv—toured England in 1945, and that Jim Laker made his Ashes debut in 1948, not 1950–56. It also notes amendments to articles on Nottingham axing language and music degrees; neglect of the Congo basin rainforest; Prince Andrew’s crisis; environmental concerns over Cambridge’s ‘sustainable’ busway; Sally Rooney’s report on prisoner mistreatment; Birmingham’s Retrofit House project; and Waymo’s robotaxis on freeways. articles.title: Epstein’s long shadow: inside the 21 November Guardian Weekly
articles.trailText: The scandal that won’t go away. Plus: Can methane cuts avert climate disaster?
articles.summary: The Guardian Weekly’s 21 Nov edition spotlights fresh fallout from Jeffrey Epstein’s private emails: after months of blocking their release, Donald Trump abruptly urged House Republicans to publish all unclassified files, potentially unsealing his ties if the Senate concurs. David Smith argues Epstein’s network underscores elite immunity. Also: Fiona Harvey on methane cuts to buy time against climate disaster; Emma Graham-Harrison on US military plans for Gaza; a Nottingham homeless teen’s plight; critiques of Labour’s asylum policy; and insights on the Stranger Things finale.

articles.title: An existential battle of interests: what the Sudanese war is actually about
articles.trailText: A bitter race to claim economic and political power has divided the country and the human cost can no longer be ignored
articles.summary: Sudan’s war pits the state’s Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) against the UAE-backed Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a militia born from decades of Darfur violence. After the 2019 ouster of dictator Omar al-Bashir, SAF and RSF deferred civilian rule, then turned on those civilians and each other, fragmenting the country. The conflict, driven by competition over political and economic power, has displaced millions, killed hundreds of thousands, and unleashed mass atrocities, including renewed genocide in Darfur. Underfunded international aid and tacit Western indifference have allowed the “forgotten” war to continue. Neither side can win outright, and Sudan looks set for prolonged division and humanitarian catastrophe.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Knife crime statistics
articles.summary: This correction clarifies that latest ONS data show 0% knife-crime change in London, North Yorkshire and Suffolk and a 13% fall in Dorset, replacing earlier claims based on an undated graph. It lists further amendments to articles on Drax asthma lawsuits, crime suspect data, this week’s doctors’ strike, Sussex coastal plastic-bead spill, Belém Cop30 protests, Jaywick photo essay, AI publishing scam and Michael J Fox’s Future Boy review, and includes contacts for editorial corrections.

articles.title: CBA boss says repaying ‘excessive fees’ to low-income customers could be seen as taking shareholder money
articles.trailText: Commonwealth Bank Australia– which reported a record cash profit of $10.3bn in most recent financial year – charged $270m in ‘excessive fees’ over five years
articles.summary: At a parliamentary hearing, Commonwealth Bank Australia CEO Mat Comyn rejected ASIC’s finding that CBA and Bankwest charged $270m in ‘excessive fees’ to 2.2m low-income customers over five years, arguing the charges complied with terms and conditions and that full reimbursement would constitute appropriation of shareholder funds. He offered limited goodwill gestures. The stance contrasts with Westpac’s pledge to refund nearly $10m. Consumer group Choice criticised Comyn for defending fees that should never have left customers’ accounts.

Other recently amended articles include a profile titled ‘Two more broomsticks please!’ on percussionist James Blades, Leicester’s make-or-break budget crisis, and war photographer Don McCullin’s selection of 19 key images. articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa a ‘real-time case study’ of colonialism’s legacies
articles.trailText: Destruction in Jamaica shows why climate justice cannot be separated from reparatory justice, campaigners say
articles.summary: Category 5 Hurricane Melissa devastated Jamaica’s Hanover parish, destroying heritage sites like Cold Spring’s Gurney’s Mount Baptist church, wrecking 146,000 buildings (15% surveyed), killing 45, displacing 360,000. At UN Cop30, Jamaican economist Mariama Williams and activists from Global Afrodescendant Climate Justice Collaborative and Caricom Reparations Commission argued that colonialism’s extraction created current climate vulnerabilities, linking climate justice with reparatory justice. PM Holness estimates $6–7bn damage; $150m insurance payout and UK’s £7.5m pledge fall short of calls for debt relief, scaled loss-and-damage funding and formal reparations.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

Other amendments cover claims of algorithmic YouTube sedation of children, US approval of oil and gas drilling in Alaska’s national wildlife refuge, Australia’s three free hours of solar power a day policy and a Caesar exam anecdote. articles.title: Corrections and clarifications

It lists recent amendments to articles on: Reform Party support and Farage, protests at a Kushner-linked Belgrade site, South Australia’s abortion restriction defeat, Utah’s new district map, a Florida base Christmas décor order, Epstein’s impact on MAGA, Trump on the National Guard, Birmingham’s homicide drop and olive brine reuse. Contact details provided.

articles.title: ‘We were forced to burn bodies’: will survivors of the Tadamon massacres see justice?
articles.trailText: The long read: During the conflict, the Damascus suburb became a killing field. But some of Assad’s henchmen are still around – and even working with the new government
articles.summary: In Damascus’s Tadamon district, survivors recount daily torture pits and burning of bodies by Assad’s military intelligence and allied paramilitaries between 2012 and 2015. Leaked footage identified 288 civilians executed in a single massacre and exposed the shooter, Amjad Youssef, who remains unpunished. Despite Assad’s fall in December 2024, many perpetrators—like NDF commander Fadi Saqr—operate openly under Syria’s new government, fueling public outrage and sporadic revenge killings. Residents describe mass graves unearthed by stray dogs, forced child labor to incinerate remains, and ongoing fear. With only a handful of arrests, Tadamon’s quest for accountability and transitional justice remains fraught and incomplete.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: Britain’s dedicated band of rainfall measurers
articles.trailText: From Anglesey to Ben Nevis and Burnley, observers have been gathering invaluable data for hundreds of years
articles.summary: Since Richard Towneley’s first systematic rain gauge in 1677 at Burnley, Britain’s rainfall observers have amassed centuries-long records. By 1860, George Symons founded the British Rainfall Organisation to collate hundreds of gauges nationwide. Mountaineer Clement Wragge walked a 14-mile round trip daily to Ben Nevis in 1881 for data, while Tom Bown, observing since age ten in 1948 on Anglesey, holds 75 years of records and an MBE. These rich archives underpin weather forecasting and climate models, but scientists warn volunteer contributions have declined, resulting in more data collected in the 1880s than in the past decade.

articles.title: Corrections and clarifications
articles.trailText: Frankie Boyle – an apology
articles.summary: An apology clarifies that the earlier opinion piece (‘Silence over Sudan shows the power of sportswashing’, 8 November) mistakenly claimed comedian Frankie Boyle performed in Dubai this year; he has not appeared there for over 25 years. The notice also lists recent article amendments: the US Senate advancing a funding bill to end its record government shutdown; plans to cut airline traffic by 10% at 40 airports amid the shutdown; and relief coverage after super typhoon Fung-wong killed eight and displaced over a million in the Philippines. Readers can send corrections or complaints by email, post or voicemail.

articles.title: When I met Craig he was 13 and homeless. I still thought his life might turn around. I was tragically wrong
articles.trailText: The long read: I knew he was running away from something. It wasn’t until many years later that I discovered the truth
articles.summary: In 1998, 13-year-old Craig ran away from a Nottingham children’s home, living rough in alleys, derelict squats and short-term hostels. Documentary filmmaker Pam traced his life: unaddressed sexual and physical abuse at Beechwood House, fractured family ties and systemic neglect. As an adult, Craig cycled through prison sentences, heroin addiction and low-level crime, briefly finding stability via church housing and art therapy with prison chaplains. Despite intermittent support, institutionalisation and mental health struggles persisted. Found dead at 41 in June 2025, his story exposes failures in child care, social services, housing and the justice system.

articles.title: The Crunch: the decline of Australian children’s TV; rivers in the sky; and where is western Europe?
articles.trailText: Streaming services may be forced to produce Australian content if the Labor’s long-awaited legislation passes parliament this week
articles.summary: Australia’s streaming giants (Netflix, Stan, Disney+) could be mandated to produce local drama, children’s and documentary content if Labor’s bill passes, aiming to reverse the slump to just 35 hrs of kids’ TV in 2023/24 after the Coalition scrapped quotas in 2020. Five charts spotlight: Gaza’s monumental recovery beneath 61 m t of rubble; hurricane-hunter aircraft probing storms like Melissa; rising integrated vapour transport fuelling floods (e.g., Spain 2024); conflicting definitions of western Europe; and the US census’s race categories evolving from a single ‘white’ option in 1790 to multiple identities after 2000.
